G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action under G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the amount in controversy exceeds $50,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Suffolk County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the acts and omissions complained of occurred in Suffolk County, Massachusetts.

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing harm to others.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the elements of negligence, including breach of a duty of reasonable care and causation, but it does not articulate a general Massachusetts rule that "every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid causing harm to others." The court expressly declines to decide whether the defendant even owed a duty of care, resolving the case solely on lack of causation. Thus, this case does not serve as authority for the broad, universal duty proposition cited.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696.relevant_excerpt:
The plaintiffs argue that they presented sufficient evidence to warrant a trial of each of their negligence claims. With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss.
...
Because the plaintiffs have failed to meet their burden on the issue of causation, we need not decide whether they presented sufficient evidence to show that the defendant owed a duty of care to them sufficient to survive the defendant’s motion for summary judgment.

*Massachusetts General Laws c. 90, \u00a.proposition: See *Massachusetts General Laws c. 90, § 14*, which requires that motorists exercise “due care” and explicitly protects bicyclists by prohibiting actions like opening car doors into traffic without precaution.

*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.raw_text: *Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 438 Mass. 317, 319 (2002)
*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.proposition: Defendant is vicariously liable for the negligence of its driver under the doctrine of respondeat superior because the acts and omissions occurred within the scope of the driver’s employment or engagement with Defendant.
*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.case_name: Dias v. Brigham Medical Associates, Inc.
*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses vicarious liability under respondeat superior and explains that once an employer–employee relationship is established, the employer is liable for torts committed by the employee within the scope of employment, without needing to control the specific acts. The court vacates summary judgment precisely because there is a factual issue whether the physician’s alleged negligence occurred while acting within the scope of his employment by BMA. This aligns with the proposition that a defendant is vicariously liable for a driver/agent’s negligence if the conduct occurred within the scope of employment or engagement.
*Dias v. Brigham Med. Assocs., Inc.*, 43.relevant_excerpt: “To prevail against BMA, the plaintiffs need only establish that (1) at the time of the alleged negligence Dr. Schlitzer was an employee of BMA, and (2) the alleged negligent treatment of the plaintiff occurred within the scope of Dr. Schlitzer’s employment by BMA. Once employment is established, the only remaining issue is whether he was working for BMA at the time of the alleged negligent treatment, i.e., whether his treatment of the plaintiff was within the scope of his employment by BMA.… All that remains to be determined is whether the tort occurred within the scope of employment.”
